docs.snippet: Chris Mullin admits there were times when he missed his old teammates early this season, particularly when St. John's lost seven of eight games and fell far behind in the Big East Conference.     ''It was a transition time,'' the smooth junior say...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chris Mullin admits there were times when he missed his old teammates early this season, particularly when St. John's lost seven of eight games and fell far behind in the Big East Conference. ''It was a transition time,'' the smooth junior says. ''There were a lot of new players, and we all had to get to know each other. But that time is over now.''

docs.snippet: It was vintage Jack Paar all the way. Jack Paar in person, aged 65. Jack Paar up on the screen, much bigger than life, with clips of his old television programs from the 1950's and 60's. A bit pudgy, a bit edgy, but still with that mischievous gli...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was vintage Jack Paar all the way. Jack Paar in person, aged 65. Jack Paar up on the screen, much bigger than life, with clips of his old television programs from the 1950's and 60's. A bit pudgy, a bit edgy, but still with that mischievous glint in his eye, the slow take he learned from Jack Benny, the impish grin. Mr. Paar was at the Museum of Broadcasting last Thursday for a ''seminar'' that was really a performance. In New York on a rare trip from his home in Connecticut, the man who kept America up late by making midnight television a ''must'' for millions will appear again tomorrow for a repeat show from 6 to 8 P.M. The museum is at One East 53d Street.

docs.snippet: The week's most promising new cable fare is the 1982 film version of ''Sophie's Choice,'' which won Meryl Streep an Oscar. Janet Maslin of The New York Times wrote that it ''casts a powerful, uninterrupted spell'' while ''retaining both the streng...
docs.lead_paragraph: The week's most promising new cable fare is the 1982 film version of ''Sophie's Choice,'' which won Meryl Streep an Oscar. Janet Maslin of The New York Times wrote that it ''casts a powerful, uninterrupted spell'' while ''retaining both the strengths and weaknesses'' of William Styron's novel, as adapted by director Alan J. Pakula.

docs.snippet: R EVOLUTION in Iran and the Soviet move into Afghanistan seem remote from the life of Stafford Springs, a town of 9,200 residents on the northeastern border of Connecticut.     Equally removed is the high-pressure world of Seventh Avenue and Ameri...
docs.lead_paragraph: R EVOLUTION in Iran and the Soviet move into Afghanistan seem remote from the life of Stafford Springs, a town of 9,200 residents on the northeastern border of Connecticut. Equally removed is the high-pressure world of Seventh Avenue and America's top clothing designers. But Stafford Springs has a very real stake in what happens in Iran and Afghanistan - and Seventh Avenue - through the town's leading business, Warren of Stafford. Warren's small complex of classic 19th-century brick and stone mill buildings houses a textile company, one of only two in the United States, that processes animal hair fiber - most of which comes from the Middle and Far East - into such luxury fabrics as camel hair, cashmere, mohair and alpaca. Warren also produces high-quality wool, cotton and felt, but its chief stock in trade is the fine fabric purchased by such clients as designers Bill Blass, Oscar de la Renta, Stanley Blacker, and top-of-the-line companies such as Hart, Shaffner & Marks, Palm Beach and the American division of Christian Dior.

headline.main: MILL TOWN HAS STAKE IN 2 WORLDS

docs.snippet: A fter one has watched movies for a living over a period of years, the surprises become increasingly rare. It's not that one's senses have been dulled, though that can happen after a stretch of films that are neither very good nor very bad. Those ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A fter one has watched movies for a living over a period of years, the surprises become increasingly rare. It's not that one's senses have been dulled, though that can happen after a stretch of films that are neither very good nor very bad. Those are the ones that anesthetize the senses. Rather it's that very few films come along about which one doesn't have some expectations - high or low - because of previous work by the same directors, writers or actors. Also, one would have to lead an impossibly cloistered life not to be aware occasionally of the annunciations of the publicity and advertising people who, like Satan, never sleep. Only once in a while does a very good and sometimes great film suddenly appear on the scene without - is it all right to say? - warning.

headline.main: A GREAT CAMERAMAN WEAVES AN EPIC SPELL

docs.snippet: Last night was special in Madison Square Garden. Much of the sellout crowd of 19,591 paid their money to cheer and pay tribute to the best basketball player in the United States Senate.    The Knicks played their cross-river rivals, the Nets, but ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Last night was special in Madison Square Garden. Much of the sellout crowd of 19,591 paid their money to cheer and pay tribute to the best basketball player in the United States Senate. The Knicks played their cross-river rivals, the Nets, but the highlight of the evening was the halftime ceremony in which No. 24, the Knick jersey that Bill Bradley last played in during the 1976-77 season, was retired. Bradley was a Knick for 10 years, a Princeton star for 3 years, a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford for 2 and has been a Democratic Senator from New Jersey for 6.

docs.snippet: A defense lawyer yesterday rejected a deaf man as a juror in a Manhattan drug trial, arguing the man was ''not qualified'' because he could not hear or speak.   ''Because of an act of God, he cannot do certain things,'' the lawyer, Oscar Finkel, t...
docs.lead_paragraph: A defense lawyer yesterday rejected a deaf man as a juror in a Manhattan drug trial, arguing the man was ''not qualified'' because he could not hear or speak. ''Because of an act of God, he cannot do certain things,'' the lawyer, Oscar Finkel, told Justice Budd G. Goodman of State Supreme Court during jury selection.

headline.main: Lawyer Rejects Deaf Man as Juror

docs.snippet: Royal Shakespeare to play here after Olympics visit.      THE very thought of the Royal Shakespeare Company's being in the United States this summer, but not in New York, has been enough to give local theatergoers an anxiety attack. The renowned B...
docs.lead_paragraph: Royal Shakespeare to play here after Olympics visit. THE very thought of the Royal Shakespeare Company's being in the United States this summer, but not in New York, has been enough to give local theatergoers an anxiety attack. The renowned British troupe is on the entertainment agenda for the Olympics in Los Angeles. Well, New Yorkers can now relax. James M. Nederlander, the theater owner and producer, is planning to divert the Royal Shakespeare Company to Broadway before it returns to London. The troupe will come here with two productions that are to play in repertory - ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' and ''Much Ado About Nothing.''

docs.snippet: ''Terms of Endearment,'' a tragicomic movie about the relationship between a mother and daughter, today led the Academy Award nominations as expected, receiving 11 in nine separate categories.    The major surprises in the nominations announced by...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Terms of Endearment,'' a tragicomic movie about the relationship between a mother and daughter, today led the Academy Award nominations as expected, receiving 11 in nine separate categories. The major surprises in the nominations announced by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences included the spurning of two big-star performances and the nominating of several specialized low-budget movies - all costing less than $5 million and most less than $4 million - for two or more major awards. The low- budget films include ''Reuben, Reuben,'' ''Tender Mercies,'' ''Fanny and Alexander,'' ''Educating Rita,'' and, in particular, ''The Dresser.'' In addition to a nomination for best picture, ''The Dresser'' - which tells the story of the last days of an aging English actor and his relationship with the man who runs his backstage life - received nominations for its two leading actors, Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay; for its screenplay, and, in perhaps the day's biggest surprise, for its director, Peter Yates. ''The Dresser'' was joined in the race for best picture by ''The Big Chill,'' a comedy about seven college friends coming to terms with death and the compromises of adulthood; ''The Right Stuff,'' the story of the first seven American astronauts and the legendary test pilot who preceded them; ''Tender Mercies,'' the redemption of a country-western singer, and ''Terms of Endearment.'' The most notable omission was ''Silkwood,'' which was a runner-up for the New York Film Critics award.

docs.snippet: He talked about Roy Smalley's coming early to work at first base and Andre Robertson's arriving early to begin his comeback from the automobile accident, and he talked about the outfield switch of Dave Winfield to right and Steve Kemp to left. But...
docs.lead_paragraph: He talked about Roy Smalley's coming early to work at first base and Andre Robertson's arriving early to begin his comeback from the automobile accident, and he talked about the outfield switch of Dave Winfield to right and Steve Kemp to left. But when the conversation turned to relief pitching, which figures to be the topic of the spring for the Yankees, Yogi Berra turned coy. ''Oh, we got a lot of time for that,'' the Yankees' new manager said, first grinning, then laughing. He was sitting in his office at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today, anticipating the start Friday of his first spring camp as Yankee manager since 1964. He had just finished the third day of staff meetings, where he and his coaches discussed plans for the 45 days that will take the team to its season-opener in Kansas City.

headline.kicker: METS AND YANKS: THE SIGNS OF SPRING
